We then by vote may justly state, The Ploughman ranks among the great More independent than them all, Who dwell upon this earthly ball. All hail ye Farmers, young and old Push on your plOughs with courage bold! Your wealth arises from your clod, Your independence from your God. If then the plough supports the nation, And men of rank in every station, Let Kings to Farmers make bow, And every man procure plough.

LIVERPOOL MARKET.-COtton and Politics. The following accurate review ofthe state of Trade ,d Pol;t;cs in England from " first rate source, x ofl,tost date has been received by the editors oi the New-York Statesman.

 I intended Dear Sir, by the packet ship Leeds' To write of the times and political creeds; But the Canada, Rogers will follow so soon, I've deferr'd my despatches till this day at noon The health of the state, all the doctors agree, Reouir'd the free use de Ia plebotomste; MT Canning was sent for, and said he was sure The disease would admit of a radical cure, If the Magdalen part of the workers ofevil- The rank tory ieeches were sent to the d--l. So out went the sepers, the Chancellor first, For he had his majesty's conscience in trust; The others soon foIlow'd, as follow they should His Maesty's conscience 'tis well understood, When left to himself does great deal of good.l Without much compuncton the lord Prlvy Seal Was made to tread hard on the Chancellor's heel After him trotted Melville and Prince Waterloo, The former turn'd yellow, the latter turn'd blue. The other two nobles who left i'll disgust, Have since begd the king to restore them their trust AIr Peel is much lik'd, but his majesty planes His dogged resistance of Catholic CIasmS, And would he but mind his 'Departmesa, the 9ione, Eythout wagng war against Ireland and Rome-- Would he only discourse about Cotton and Corn, He would be the;best Tory that ever was born: Even Orange-men then would undoubtedly feel, There was nothing of bitterness lefti the Peel. The Coloaiol question, was ofan hour And do what we may, we must take your flour; You will get the long freight, and your seamen will

 ehun The baneful effects of tropical sun. As to timber and lumberthe Huskissom plan, Will make us plant acorns for aye if he can In patent beach'd goods and in goods in the rough, The country till lately has done well enough; But the terrible bug about cotton and corn, Has render'd the calico trade most foriorn, The landholders calld for duty on grain, And have got one that falls and then rises again One that lifts like dock, when the tide is afiood, And sinks when it ebbs, and will do them no good. A shrewd "tester tauter" of Cannings device, To raise or drop grain by the weight ofthe price. Naval Stores stick hand, but Tnrpentine's scarce, For ts lately discover'd twill make a fine gas; As to Pot and Pearl Ashes pray don't forget What wrote you in March-they hold the price yet. Indeed as you yankees are given to guess, quote when quote,-"be the san,e more or tess," Since were to send you the true state of trade, Igshould run small hazard of losing my bread. Monopoly now is the word ofthe day, The big fish are driving us small ones away; Now this Is Circgln, for it has run Around many topics without touching one.

 Liverpool May Is:. 12 M.

 The following lyric was originally published in the U S. Literary Gazette, and bore the signature of w. c. Bryant, Esq. gentleman well known in the tera- 1y world. His poetry is invariably good.

 IS THIS A TIME, sc. Is this time to be cloudy and sad,

 When our mother nature laughs aroGnd; When even the deep blue heavens look glad, And gladness breaths from the blossoming ground There are notes ofjoy from the hang birdand wren, And the gossip eff swallows through all the sky, Ths sround-squirrel gay chirps by his den, Ana fhe sildiag bee huns meriyby. The clo uls are at play in the azure space' And their shadows play the bright green Vaie' And here they stretch to the fro[c chase,

 And there they roll on the easy gale ,There's darce ofleaves in that aspen bower, There's litter of winds in that beachen ree' Theres smile on the fruit and smile on the ho"r' And laugh from the brook that runs from tke sea- And look at the broad-fac'd san how he smiles On the dewey earth that smilesinh his ray. sOn the Ieaping waters, and gay young isles,

 Ay look, and he'll smile thy gloom away. 

 From the dmerican Farmer.

 THE FARMER

 Of all pursuits by man invented

 The Ploughman is the best contented;

 His calIng's good, his profits high'

 And on his Iabours all rely;

 Mechanics all by him are fed,

 Of him the Merchants seek their bread'

 His hands give meat to every thing'

 Up from the beggar to the king

 The milk and honey, corn and wheat,

 Are by his labOurs made complete;

 Our clothes from him must first arise,

 TO deck the Eop or dress the wise;

Warren, and Andrew T. Judson Commissioners duly

 appointed and commissioned the part of the State

 to ascertain and establish the Boundary line between

Mills, Leonard M. Parker, and John Mills, Commissioners the part of { ger Stoddard Moses Warren, and Andrew T. Jud- son, Commissioners the part of the State of Con-

 necticu having had various meetings and consulta-

 tions and by the aid of Epaphras Hoyt, Esq Surveyor on the part of Massachusetts, and Jonathan Nichols, Esq. Surveyor the part of Connecticut, have run and surveyed the following lines upon parallel of

 latitude, to wit Commencing survey the North East corner of the State of Connecticut being large pile ofstones erected by the commissioners of the re- spective governments, in the year of our Lord one thousand hundred and thirty -four thence run ming West, nearly as could be ascertained the latitude of fortyWO degrees and three minutes North touching the North-East corner of John Batys House. formerly Nathaniel Brown's) to the west line of Woodstock, the whole distance being fifteen miles and one hundred aud sxty-nine rods and fifteen links ;- thence we run course North three degrees West by the true meridian, fifty four rods and nineteen links old pine tree the reputed Northeast corner of the Union; thence we run West, the latitude of the said old pine tree, being north fifty four rods of the said first line of latitude, to Connecticut River which we struck two hundred and twenty-wo rods North of the Northwest corner of Enfield; the whole dis tance from said old pine tree to the river being twenty-five miles and one hundred and sixty-eight rods.

 We made careful admeasurements from the afore- said lines of latitude reputed bounds and monuments each side of said lines, and collected all

 tablished by Commissioners on the part of the two colonies, in the year of Lord thousand hundred and thirteen; And having out said lines oflattude as aforesaid, and compared the same with the ancient surveys, monuments and other evidence collected by us of the line aforesaid Com- mssioners in the year of our Lord thousand sev- en hundred and thirteen, found the said lines of latitude to vary in sundry places therefrom: ., For the purpose therefore, of conforming to said line of seventeen hundred andthrteen the line of jurisdiction far as the could be ascerained by ancient monuments, and long continued practical jurisdiction, have surveyed, run out, ascerained and established the boundary line hereinafter descri

 bed, and have established the the line of

 jurisdiction between the Commonwealth of Massachu- sets and the State of Connecticut of Connecticut River; and we have marked said lines and erected suitable monuments thereon, in the places hercinaf- ter mentioned, to prevent future mistakes and dis putes.

 Which said line, so ascertained and established is follows, to wit Beginning at the aforesaid North East corner of Connecticut, where erected ument, and running West the line of latitude first above mentioned which line we herein designate as the first line of latitude passing the ancentheap of stones on Bald Hill, and touching the North-Eas corner of John Bates house the road leading from Thompson, by the Merino Factory, called the Merino road, where erected monument; the distance be- tween these points being thousand hundred and two rods and four lnks and in range between these points erected five monuments, to wit in the Oxford gore road, so called; one the road leading from Thompson by John Bates to Oxford !; Freeman's to Dudley, one the road leading from Thompson by Joseph Brackets to Dudley ,and one on 1 the road leading from Thompson by Dudley. BY THE GOVERNOR OF THE STATE OF

 CONNECTICUT. g"
A PROCLAMATION.

The New Monthly Magazine gives the following method of obtaining flowers of different colours on the same stem Split small twig of elder length apartments with seeds of flowers of different sorts. but which blossom about the same time surround them with mould, and then tying together the two bits of wood plant the whole pot filed with earth, properly prepared. The stems of the dherentow will thus be incorporated as to exhibit to the eye only one stem, throwing out branches covered with flowers analogous to the seed which produced them.

 All EBENEZER YOUNG, &e Speaker of the House of Representatives.

GIDEON ToMLrNSON.

An Act in addition to an act entitled, "An Act pre- scribing the mode of proceeding, by hte General Assembly, in certain cases."

 SEC. l. Be it enacted by the Senae and House of Representatives in Geer Assembly convened, That no member of the General Assembly shall appear as an Attorney at the bar of said Assembly, before any committee of said Assembly, or before committed of either branch thereof unless in his own cause or that of the Town which he represents or any society or corporation therein, in such where there shall be so relation between such member and either of the parties in the cases as between father and son. either by nature marriage. brother in like kind, cc or nephew in like kind, landlord and tenant.

 SEC. ,. If any member of the General Assembly shall hereafter appear Attorney in any cases contra ry the provisions of this act then his seat shall be vacated in said Assembly, and he is hereby declared incapable of holdiug the same, or to act member of said Assembly during the term for which he shall have been elected.

 EBENEZER YOUNG,

 Speaker of the House of Representatives.

 JOHN 5. PETERS,

 President of the Senate. GIDEON TOMIJNSON.

May 29th, 1a27-Approved.

 GIDEON TOMLINSON.

CTS to take the acknowledgement and proof of deeds ana instruments under seal and dispositions,

 SEC. l. Be enacted by the Se,sate and House of Representatives in General Assembly conuened That the Governor ofthis State be- and is hereby authorised to name, appoint and commission one or more com mssioners in each such of the other states of the United States or in the District of Columbia as he may deem expedient, which Commissioner shall continue m office during the pleasure cf the Governor ef this sate and shall have authority to take the acknowIedg- ment and proof of any deed, mortgage, other con- vcyance ofany lands, tenements. hereditamcns y- Ing or beng Tn this state or any other writing under sea to be used or improved in this state, and such knowledgement or proof taken CT made in the manner directed by the laws of this state and certified by the Commissioner, before whom the same shall be taken or made, shall have the same force and effect and be as good and available in a for all purposes, as if the same had been made taken before of the Judges of the Supreme Court ofthe United States. r.. SEC.2. That every Commissioner appointed by vir- tue ot this act, shall have full power and authority to administer an oath, or affirmation to any person who shall be willing, or desirous to make such an oath or affirmation before him; and to take dispositions, and to examine witnesses, under any commission com missions emanatng from any of the courts of thisstae, relating to any depending or to be brought on in any of said courts and every deposition, affidavit or affirmation, made before such commissioner, shall and is hereby declared to be good and eectual to all ntents and purposes, as if taken before oficer resident in this state, and competent to take the same.

 SEC. 3. That every commissioner appointed as a. foresad, before he shall proceed to perform any duty, under and by virtue of this act shall take and subscribe an oath or affirmation, before Justice of the Peace in the city county, in which such commissioner shall reside, well and faithfully to execute and per- form all the duties of such commissioner, under and by virtue of the laws of Connecticut which oath or affirmation shall be filed in the office of the Secretary of this state.

 EBENEZER YOUNG,

 Speaker of the House of Representatives

 JOHN s. PETERS,

 t President of the Senate. Approved--Jane1 1, 1927.
GIDEON TOMLINSON.

We then by vote may justly state, The Ploughman ranks among the great More independent than them all, Who dwell upon this earthly ball. All hail ye Farmers, young and old Push on your plOughs with courage bold! Your wealth arises from your clod, Your independence from your God. If then the plough supports the nation, And men of rank in every station, Let Kings to Farmers make bow, And every man procure plough.

LIVERPOOL MARKET.-COtton and Politics. The following accurate review ofthe state of Trade ,d Pol;t;cs in England from " first rate source, x ofl,tost date has been received by the editors oi the New-York Statesman.

 I intended Dear Sir, by the packet ship Leeds' To write of the times and political creeds; But the Canada, Rogers will follow so soon, I've deferr'd my despatches till this day at noon The health of the state, all the doctors agree, Reouir'd the free use de Ia plebotomste; MT Canning was sent for, and said he was sure The disease would admit of a radical cure, If the Magdalen part of the workers ofevil- The rank tory ieeches were sent to the d--l. So out went the sepers, the Chancellor first, For he had his majesty's conscience in trust; The others soon foIlow'd, as follow they should His Maesty's conscience 'tis well understood, When left to himself does great deal of good.l Without much compuncton the lord Prlvy Seal Was made to tread hard on the Chancellor's heel After him trotted Melville and Prince Waterloo, The former turn'd yellow, the latter turn'd blue. The other two nobles who left i'll disgust, Have since begd the king to restore them their trust AIr Peel is much lik'd, but his majesty planes His dogged resistance of Catholic CIasmS, And would he but mind his 'Departmesa, the 9ione, Eythout wagng war against Ireland and Rome-- Would he only discourse about Cotton and Corn, He would be the;best Tory that ever was born: Even Orange-men then would undoubtedly feel, There was nothing of bitterness lefti the Peel. The Coloaiol question, was ofan hour And do what we may, we must take your flour; You will get the long freight, and your seamen will

 ehun The baneful effects of tropical sun. As to timber and lumberthe Huskissom plan, Will make us plant acorns for aye if he can In patent beach'd goods and in goods in the rough, The country till lately has done well enough; But the terrible bug about cotton and corn, Has render'd the calico trade most foriorn, The landholders calld for duty on grain, And have got one that falls and then rises again One that lifts like dock, when the tide is afiood, And sinks when it ebbs, and will do them no good. A shrewd "tester tauter" of Cannings device, To raise or drop grain by the weight ofthe price. Naval Stores stick hand, but Tnrpentine's scarce, For ts lately discover'd twill make a fine gas; As to Pot and Pearl Ashes pray don't forget What wrote you in March-they hold the price yet. Indeed as you yankees are given to guess, quote when quote,-"be the san,e more or tess," Since were to send you the true state of trade, Igshould run small hazard of losing my bread. Monopoly now is the word ofthe day, The big fish are driving us small ones away; Now this Is Circgln, for it has run Around many topics without touching one.

 Liverpool May Is:. 12 M.

 The following lyric was originally published in the U S. Literary Gazette, and bore the signature of w. c. Bryant, Esq. gentleman well known in the tera- 1y world. His poetry is invariably good.

 IS THIS A TIME, sc. Is this time to be cloudy and sad,

 When our mother nature laughs aroGnd; When even the deep blue heavens look glad, And gladness breaths from the blossoming ground There are notes ofjoy from the hang birdand wren, And the gossip eff swallows through all the sky, Ths sround-squirrel gay chirps by his den, Ana fhe sildiag bee huns meriyby. The clo uls are at play in the azure space' And their shadows play the bright green Vaie' And here they stretch to the fro[c chase,

 And there they roll on the easy gale ,There's darce ofleaves in that aspen bower, There's litter of winds in that beachen ree' Theres smile on the fruit and smile on the ho"r' And laugh from the brook that runs from tke sea- And look at the broad-fac'd san how he smiles On the dewey earth that smilesinh his ray. sOn the Ieaping waters, and gay young isles,

 Ay look, and he'll smile thy gloom away. 

 From the dmerican Farmer.

 THE FARMER

 Of all pursuits by man invented

 The Ploughman is the best contented;

 His calIng's good, his profits high'

 And on his Iabours all rely;

 Mechanics all by him are fed,

 Of him the Merchants seek their bread'

 His hands give meat to every thing'

 Up from the beggar to the king

 The milk and honey, corn and wheat,

 Are by his labOurs made complete;

 Our clothes from him must first arise,

 TO deck the Eop or dress the wise;

From the monument on the road leading by Walter Ainsworth aforementioned, running in direct line to the road leading from Sommers, by Abel Pease's 1 Springfield, where we erected monument; the dis tance between these two points being five hundred and twenty-three rods; and the distance South from the said second line of latitude, the last mentioned monument being six rods and twelve links and in range between these points erected one monument, to wit the road leading from the East part of En- l field, by Crocker Waterlouse's, to Springfield From the monument at the road leading by Abel Peases aforementioned, running due west next until the line so run intersects the ancient line between Springfield, now Long Meadow, and Enfield, where we erected monument, the distance between these two points being six hundred and fortyfve rods; and in range between these two points, we erected one monument, to wit, on the road between Shaker Viii lage to Springfield From the monument at the point of intersection a.  The whole number Ot monuments erected by us, as aforementioned, is ortynine, all of which single Norti-East corner of Connecticut aforesaid to the Village Street road; and the reseduc to the river, the red Sand Stone from five and half tp six feet in length, from ten to twelve inchesin breadth; aud from six to eight inches in thickness sunk two and

full articles.headline:
BY THE GOVERNOR OF THE STATE OF

 CONNECTICUT. g"

A PROCLAMATION.
full articles.article:
Warren, and Andrew T. Judson Commissioners duly

 appointed and commissioned the part of the State

 of Connecticut, and the Hon. Elijah H. Mills, Leon-

 ard M. Parker, and John Mills, Commissioners duly

 appointed and commissioned the part of tEe Coml-

 monwealth of Massachusetts pursuant to certain Res

 olutons of the Legislatures of said states respectively,

 to ascertain and establish the Boundary line between

 the said State of Connecticut, and the Commonwealth of Massachusetts East of Connecticut River so far as

 the same in dispute, by certain instrument and

 agreement in writing by them subscribed in duplicate

 and dated Southbrdge in Massachusetts, on the third day of November, thousand eight hundred and twentysix did agree upon aud determine the said line, and define and describe the same in the following words that is to say "We the undersigned Elijah H. Mills, Leonard M. Parker, and John Mills, Commissioners the part of { ger Stoddard Moses Warren, and Andrew T. Jud- son, Commissioners the part of the State of Con-

 necticu having had various meetings and consulta-

 tions and by the aid of Epaphras Hoyt, Esq Surveyor on the part of Massachusetts, and Jonathan Nichols, Esq. Surveyor the part of Connecticut, have run and surveyed the following lines upon parallel of

 latitude, to wit Commencing survey the North East corner of the State of Connecticut being large pile ofstones erected by the commissioners of the re- spective governments, in the year of our Lord one thousand hundred and thirty -four thence run ming West, nearly as could be ascertained the latitude of fortyWO degrees and three minutes North touching the North-East corner of John Batys House. formerly Nathaniel Brown's) to the west line of Woodstock, the whole distance being fifteen miles and one hundred aud sxty-nine rods and fifteen links ;- thence we run course North three degrees West by the true meridian, fifty four rods and nineteen links old pine tree the reputed Northeast corner of the Union; thence we run West, the latitude of the said old pine tree, being north fifty four rods of the said first line of latitude, to Connecticut River which we struck two hundred and twenty-wo rods North of the Northwest corner of Enfield; the whole dis tance from said old pine tree to the river being twenty-five miles and one hundred and sixty-eight rods.

 We made careful admeasurements from the afore- said lines of latitude reputed bounds and monuments each side of said lines, and collected all

 tablished by Commissioners on the part of the two colonies, in the year of Lord thousand hundred and thirteen; And having out said lines oflattude as aforesaid, and compared the same with the ancient surveys, monuments and other evidence collected by us of the line aforesaid Com- mssioners in the year of our Lord thousand sev- en hundred and thirteen, found the said lines of latitude to vary in sundry places therefrom: ., For the purpose therefore, of conforming to said line of seventeen hundred andthrteen the line of jurisdiction far as the could be ascerained by ancient monuments, and long continued practical jurisdiction, have surveyed, run out, ascerained and established the boundary line hereinafter descri

 bed, and have established the the line of

 jurisdiction between the Commonwealth of Massachu- sets and the State of Connecticut of Connecticut River; and we have marked said lines and erected suitable monuments thereon, in the places hercinaf- ter mentioned, to prevent future mistakes and dis putes.

 Which said line, so ascertained and established is follows, to wit Beginning at the aforesaid North East corner of Connecticut, where erected ument, and running West the line of latitude first above mentioned which line we herein designate as the first line of latitude passing the ancentheap of stones on Bald Hill, and touching the North-Eas corner of John Bates house the road leading from Thompson, by the Merino Factory, called the Merino road, where erected monument; the distance be- tween these points being thousand hundred and two rods and four lnks and in range between these points erected five monuments, to wit in the Oxford gore road, so called; one the road leading from Thompson by John Bates to Oxford !; Freeman's to Dudley, one the road leading from Thompson by Joseph Brackets to Dudley ,and one on 1 the road leading from Thompson by Dudley. From the monument at the Merino Road aforementioned, running in direct line, passing the ancient heap of stones at the North East corner of Woodstock, the road leading from Muddy Brook, so called by Penuel Mays to Southbridge, where erected a monument; the distance between those two points rods and twenty links and the distance North from

 said first line of latitude to the last mentioned mon-

 ment, being twenty-one rods and ten links; and in

 range between these points erected five monuments to wit, one on the road leading from Thompson by Richard Arnold's to Dudley; one the road leading from Woodstock by David Nichols, to Dudley; one on the road leading from Barns to the Thompson Turnpike; and one on the road leading from Muddy Brook, called, by Samuel Thompson's to South bridge.

 From the the monument to the road leading by Pe- nue Mays aforementioned running in direct line to fine NorIvch and Woodstock Turnpike, where we er- ected a monument, the distance between these two points beng three hundred and sixty rods and five iinks and the distance North from said first line of

 latitude to the last mentoVed monuments being twen ty rods and five links.

 y Erom inc monument at the Norwich and Wood stock Turnpike aforementioned, running in di- reef line to the road leading from West Woodstock bv Abel Mason's Southbridge, where erected a n,onument; the distance between these two points he;no nine hundred fifty four rods and eighteen lnks and fhe distance North from said line of latitude, the

 Iast mentioned monuHent being ten rods and twenty two links; and in a range between these two points, we erected two monuments to wit. one the Leba- non- road, so called and one on the road leading from West Woodstock, by Nathan Browns to South bridge.

 Masons aforementioned running in direct line pas

 sing twenty-four rods and eighteen links south of the

 of Union to the road leading from Union, to Asher 1 Radger's to Holland, where we erected a monument

 te distance between these two points being one thou

 sand two hundred forty rods and the distance

 South from the latitude of the old pine tree, Which

 we herein designate as the second line of latitude, be-

 ng txyo rods and three.fourths links the last l toned monments and in range between these points,

full articles.article: The New Monthly Magazine gives the following method of obtaining flowers of different colours on the same stem Split small twig of elder length apartments with seeds of flowers of different sorts. but which blossom about the same time surround them with mould, and then tying together the two bits of wood plant the whole pot filed with earth, properly prepared. The stems of the dherentow will thus be incorporated as to exhibit to the eye only one stem, throwing out branches covered with flowers analogous to the seed which produced them.

 All EBENEZER YOUNG, &e Speaker of the House of Representatives.

 JOHN s. PETERS,

An Act in addition to an act entitled, "An Act pre- scribing the mode of proceeding, by hte General Assembly, in certain cases."

 SEC. l. Be it enacted by the Senae and House of Representatives in Geer Assembly convened, That no member of the General Assembly shall appear as an Attorney at the bar of said Assembly, before any committee of said Assembly, or before committed of either branch thereof unless in his own cause or that of the Town which he represents or any society or corporation therein, in such where there shall be so relation between such member and either of the parties in the cases as between father and son. either by nature marriage. brother in like kind, cc or nephew in like kind, landlord and tenant.

 SEC. ,. If any member of the General Assembly shall hereafter appear Attorney in any cases contra ry the provisions of this act then his seat shall be vacated in said Assembly, and he is hereby declared incapable of holdiug the same, or to act member of said Assembly during the term for which he shall have been elected.

 EBENEZER YOUNG,

 Speaker of the House of Representatives.

 JOHN 5. PETERS,

 President of the Senate. GIDEON TOMIJNSON.

Of all pursuits by man invented The Ploughman is the best contented; His calIing's good, his profits high' And on his Iabours all rely;

 Mechanics all by him are fed, Of him the Merchants seek their bread' His hands give meat to every thing' Up from the beggar to the king. The milk and honey, corn and wheat Are by his labOurs made complete; Our clothes from him must first arise, To deck tbe flop or dress the wise;

full articles.article:
l WHEREAS, the congress of the United States, by

 an act passed on the 18th day of May, A. D. 1826 thorized the building of Light House in the State of Connectcutat or near the mouth of Norwalk Harbor and appropriated the sum of four thousand dollars therefor -and whereas the United Ststes have pur- chased for the site of said Light House. and other ne- cessay buildings the lot piece of land described l follows, viz:-- certain piece or parcel of land, situated in the town of Norwak' in Fairfield county,on the West end of Norwak L. called, in quantity three acres of upland, and bounded Northerly by Norwak Harbour, Westerly by the Point, Southerly by Long Isl- and, and Easterly on the land of Gershom B. Smith :''--

 Ben enacted by the Senate and House of Represe1- tatires in General Assembly conyeaed, That His Ex- cellency the Governor be, and is hereby authorised and empowered to cede the jurisdiction of this State over the said tract of land above described and so

 purchased by the United States, the said United

CTS to take the acknowledgement and proof of deeds ana instruments under seal and dispositions,

 SEC. l. Be enacted by the Se,sate and House of Representatives in General Assembly conuened That the Governor ofthis State be- and is hereby authorised to name, appoint and commission one or more com mssioners in each such of the other states of the United States or in the District of Columbia as he may deem expedient, which Commissioner shall continue m office during the pleasure cf the Governor ef this sate and shall have authority to take the acknowIedg- ment and proof of any deed, mortgage, other con- vcyance ofany lands, tenements. hereditamcns y- Ing or beng Tn this state or any other writing under sea to be used or improved in this state, and such knowledgement or proof taken CT made in the manner directed by the laws of this state and certified by the Commissioner, before whom the same shall be taken or made, shall have the same force and effect and be as good and available in a for all purposes, as if the same had been made taken before of the Judges of the Supreme Court ofthe United States. r.. SEC.2. That every Commissioner appointed by vir- tue ot this act, shall have full power and authority to administer an oath, or affirmation to any person who shall be willing, or desirous to make such an oath or affirmation before him; and to take dispositions, and to examine witnesses, under any commission com missions emanatng from any of the courts of thisstae, relating to any depending or to be brought on in any of said courts and every deposition, affidavit or affirmation, made before such commissioner, shall and is hereby declared to be good and eectual to all ntents and purposes, as if taken before oficer resident in this state, and competent to take the same.

 SEC. 3. That every commissioner appointed as a. foresad, before he shall proceed to perform any duty, under and by virtue of this act shall take and subscribe an oath or affirmation, before Justice of the Peace in the city county, in which such commissioner shall reside, well and faithfully to execute and per- form all the duties of such commissioner, under and by virtue of the laws of Connecticut which oath or affirmation shall be filed in the office of the Secretary of this state.

 EBENEZER YOUNG,

 Speaker of the House of Representatives

 JOHN s. PETERS,

 t President of the Senate. Approved--Jane1 1, 1927.
